Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was about to head to my brother’s room. He’d been quiet all day, and Mom mentioned he seemed down after a tough exam. I knew he needed me, maybe just to sit with him or listen. But then my friend Sam’s name flashed on the screen. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m losing my mind with this IKEA thing,” he texted. I could almost hear the frustration in his words. Sam had always been there for me, especially last month when I was stressed about my internship. I owed him.

But my brother—he rarely asked for help, and I could sense he was struggling. I felt torn, standing in the hallway, phone in hand. If I ignored Sam, I’d let down a friend who counted on me. If I put off my brother, I’d miss a rare chance to be there when he actually needed support. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, caught between two people who both expected me to show up for them.
